intro: Cinchona officinalis var. condaminea, commonly known as the Peruvian bark, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen tree or shrub form. The plant is notable for its dark, aromatic bark, which contains alkaloids such as quinine, historically used in the treatment of malaria. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing at high altitudes with well-drained soil. Due to its medicinal significance, it has been cultivated in various parts of the world for centuries.
